DataElement.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Clinical Distant Metastasis M Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for the carcinoma of the vulva based on evidence obtained from clinical assessment parameters determined prior to treatment.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation. The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Clinical M Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A clinical finding about one or more characteristics of vulvar cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases._A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer cM0 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer cM0 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer without evidence of distant metastasis. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer cM0 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer without evidence of distant metastasis. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer cM1 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer cM1 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with distant metastasis (including pelvic lymph node metastasis). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer cM1 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with distant metastasis (including pelvic lymph node metastasis). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer Clinical Distant Metastasis TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: A clinical finding about one or more characteristics of vulvar cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases.
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
